Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral dissertation research: Linguistic avoidance and social relations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
What is the role of language in how we manage our relationships with other people? This dissertation project investigates this question from the perspective of a Tanzanian language called Datooga, which has a special respect vocabulary used only by women. Out of respect for their husbands' families, married women avoid saying the names of their in-laws, as well as any ordinary words in the language that sound like these names. To be able to talk freely while still observing the taboo, Datooga women have developed an entire additional vocabulary, distinct from that of the ordinary language. "Avoidance registers," as these special vocabularies are known, are rare across the world's languages, but have arisen independently in several parts of Africa, as well as in Mongolia and Australia. Unfortunately, we currently have an incomplete picture of how these avoidance registers work, because most previous research has relied on interviews with speakers rather than observation of actual speech. This dissertation project will provide the first comprehensive documentation of an avoidance register in everyday use.

Avoidance registers are important for the study of language because they illustrate strikingly the social function of language; they are motivated solely by interpersonal concerns relating to gender, kinship, and social status. To explore the social dynamics of the Datooga avoidance register, this project involves collecting, transcribing, and analysing audio-visual recordings of spontaneous interaction in Datooga homesteads, as well as compiling a database of avoidance vocabulary. Fieldwork will be conducted in Manyara Region, Tanzania, and data will be collected from several families across the region. This project will significantly advance our understanding of linguistic avoidance and its role in social life, while also building on our knowledge of an understudied language and making a unique contribution to the documentation of the world's linguistic diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award provided funding for a PhD research project on the dynamics of in-law name avoidance among Datooga speakers of Tanzania. Datooga is one of Tanzania’s 150+ languages and is spoken by semi-nomadic cattle herders predominantly in the northern part of the country. In Datooga society, women show respect to their senior in-laws by avoiding saying not only their names but also ordinary words that sound like their names. Over time, a special avoidance vocabulary has developed that provides conventional alternatives for all words a woman might need to avoid. For example, if we were to do this in English, a woman whose father-in-law was called “Tom” would avoid the words “Tom,” “tomato,” “tomorrow,” “tom-cat,” etc., and replace these words with alternative forms, perhaps saying “pomodoro” or “red fruit” instead of “tomato.” By researching understudied phenomena such as this one, we get a more complete picture of the world’s sociolinguistic diversity; that is, diversity in how humans use language to organize themselves socially. While similar systems of avoidance have been documented in other cultures, this project aimed to collect the first naturalistic data of this kind of in-law name avoidance. The main research goals were to document and describe the actual practice of in-law name avoidance among Datooga women, and then to analyze how women construct social relationships through this linguistic avoidance.

The award provided the means for seven months of linguistic-anthropological fieldwork in several Datooga households in Mbulu District, Manyara Region. The co-PI made audio-visual recordings of women’s everyday conversations in these households, conducted interviews with women and men about avoidance practices and family life, and collected over 650 items of the avoidance vocabulary. With the help of several Datooga-speaking research assistants, the co-PI transcribed around sixteen hours of the recorded conversations and translated them into both Swahili, Tanzania’s lingua franca, and English. Analysis of this data revealed greater flexibility in women’s avoidance practices than we had previously assumed: women did not avoid all taboo words under all circumstances, and they tended to avoid more prominent in-laws, such as father-in-law, to a greater degree than other in-laws, thereby paying him greater respect. These findings are presented in the co-PI’s dissertation, which also contains a large glossary of avoidance vocabulary. Such documentation is particularly valuable in light of the fact that avoidance practices are, predictably, on the decline among Datooga speakers, whose culture is changing rapidly in response to industrializing, modernizing forces in Tanzania, as well as the spread of world religions.

In addition to its intellectual merits, project outcomes include the training of a graduate student and acquisition of new skills by both her and her research assistants in Tanzania. The project necessitated cross-cultural collaboration, which naturally led to increased cross-cultural understanding, too. As a marginalized community in Tanzania, let alone the rest of the world, Datooga speakers can draw some pride and self-worth from the sustained scholarly interest in their language and culture represented by this project. The principal outcome of the project—the PhD dissertation—brings voices to the fore that are otherwise rarely heard in Western sociolinguistics.
